name: NewYorker
text: In the summer of 1967, a young black boy in Brooklyn was shot in the back by a police officer. Hilton Als recalls the two days of “discord and sadness” that followed. Listen here, or wherever you get your podcasts. https://t.co/mHocsAICI3

name: NewYorker
text: Retaining the support of seniors is central to President Trump’s reëlection chances. But a number of polls released this week show that he has slipped badly in this key demographic. https://t.co/OefO8zMJH6

name: NewYorker
text: Charles Burnett’s 2003 documentary, “Nat Turner: A Troublesome Property,” charts how authors have both formed and deformed history’s view of Turner and his slave rebellion. https://t.co/vPfJcIHjsa

name: NewYorker
text: On July 2, @Caramoor, a summertime classical-music destination near Katonah, New York, inaugurates a boldly reconceived festival, featuring both online concerts and outdoor events. https://t.co/6jfELN5svU https://t.co/fHqWYIHjpp

name: NewYorker
text: Is Jon Stewart’s new comedy, "Irresistable," starring Steve Carell, a sendup of big-time political operatives or of small-town America? https://t.co/JXjaINtKNp

name: NewYorker
text: Spike Lee’s new film, “Da 5 Bloods,” pulls the traumas of black men’s experiences of the Vietnam War out of obscurity and puts them in the forefront of political consciousness. https://t.co/BuZJakUa8g

name: NewYorker
text: When asked about his opponent's campaigning style, Madison Cawthorn mimicked her in an expressionless voice: “First and foremost, I am a Christian. My strength comes from the Lord. I am endorsed by President Trump and endorsed by Mark Meadows." https://t.co/NyvCTwt6cL
